intro: Net income is your total income after taxes, deductions, credits, and business operating expenses. There is a slightly different process for calculating your personal net income, and calculating your business net income. It involves looking through some records and doing a bit of math, but calculating your net income is simple once you know the process.

steps.title: Subtract what you owe in taxes from your annual pay.
steps.subtitle: After you've found out what your total taxable income is, then you have to subtract the amount you owe in taxes.
sub-points: Add up all taxes you owe, including federal, state, local, Medicare and social security. If your employer takes out taxes, then the total deductions should be on your pay stubs.
Subtract the total taxes from your income to get your net annual income.

Sticking with the previous example: if your gross income was $50,000, you had $5,000 in deductions, and you deducted another $2,000 for retirement, your taxable income is $43,000. Then if you owe $10,000 in taxes, that makes your net income $33,000.
If at any point you're confused about your taxes, consulting an accountant will help clear things up.

Sticking with the previous example: if your gross income was $50,000, you had $5,000 in deductions, and you deducted another $2,000 for retirement, your taxable income is $43,000. Then if you owe $10,000 in taxes, that makes your net income $33,000.
If at any point you're confused about your taxes, consulting an accountant will help clear things up.

steps.title: Subtract your tax obligations from your taxable income.
steps.subtitle: After you figure out what you owe in taxes, subtract that number from your taxable income. Once you do this, then you've arrived at your business net income.
sub-points: Let's say that you figure out you owe $10,000 in taxes, but you have that $1,000 tax credit, so you owe $9,000. Subtract that from your taxable income of $83,000 and you get a final net income of $74,000.
